nodes.text: Machine learning algorithms can be used to predict stock market movements and thereby help investors make better buy and sell decisions
This paper uses a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) to answer research questions about the necessity, input attributes, and algorithms for stock market prediction
Accurate stock market prediction is necessary because it helps investors decide when to buy at low prices and sell at high prices and reduces risk of loss

A variety of attributes and factors are used as inputs for prediction models, including market history, news and event information, public mood, commodity prices (oil, gold, silver), interest rates, foreign exchange, technical indicators, and macroeconomic variables

Researchers use multiple machine learning algorithms for stock prediction, notably linear regression, neural networks, genetic algorithms, support vector machines, k-nearest neighbor, and random forest
Combining event knowledge or extracted news information with machine learning models, particularly neural networks, improves prediction accuracy (reported increase around five percent in one study)
Stock market prediction is difficult due to dynamic changes and multiple influencing events, so model accuracy depends on choice of attributes, algorithm, and training data size
Conclusion: Machine learning algorithms are helpful for stock prediction and can assist investors in decision making, but effectiveness depends on data, attributes, and algorithm selection
Search process: initial retrieval from digital libraries yielded 550 papers which were screened by title, then abstract, then full text resulting in 45 included papers
Inclusion criteria required papers to be in English, fully available, and relevant to stock market prediction; quality assessment examined each paper author's contribution before inclusion
Empirical and literature evidence cited indicates more accurate predictions lead to greater investor profit and benefit for sellers and brokers
Evidence: Studies report that news and event features, fuel price changes, network indicators during crises, and combined event knowledge raise prediction performance
Context: Researchers have identified macroeconomic factors affecting stock trends such as consumer spending, investment, unemployment, inflation, and federal funds rate

Evidence on algorithms: Multiple studies report SVM often outperforms other classifiers for trend prediction; neural networks and hybrid approaches with text perform well for index and intraday prediction

Reported performance figures from reviewed studies include: multiple-classifier study accuracy 65 percent, random forest claimed 83 percent in one source, and another random forest study reported 64 percent
